240.01   COMPOSITION AND TABLE OF ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   The composition and Table of Organization of the Division of Fire and
Emergency Rescue Services shall be as follows:
      (1)   One (1) Fire Chief
      (2)   One (1) Medical Advisor
      (3)   One (1) Full Time Administrative Secretary
      (4)   Two (2) Part Time Records Custodians
      (5)   Two (2) Full Time Fire Captains
      (6)   Six (6) Full Time Fire Lieutenants
      (7)   Two (2) Part Time Fire Lieutenants
      (8)   Seven (7) Full Time Firefighter/EMT-P
      (9)   Forty (40) Part Time Firefighters
   (b)   The Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services Table of
Organization is only for illustration purposes and is subject to Councilmanic
funding.
(Ord. 1994-158. Passed 11-21-94; Ord. 2002-038S. Passed 5-20-02; Ord. 2006-
059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.02   CLASSIFICATION OF EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   The positions of Fire Chief, Medical Advisor, Records Custodian, Part
Time Fire Lieutenant and Part Time Firefighters shall be designated as
unclassified service; the position of Full Time Fire Captain shall be
designated as civil service, but outside of the bargaining unit; the positions
of Full Time Fire lieutenant and Full Time Firefighter/EMT-P and Administrative
Secretary and those Part Time employees who are considered intermittent Part
Time Firefighters shall be designated civil service.
(Ord. 1994-158. Passed 11-21-94; Ord. 2002-038S. Passed 5-20-02; Ord. 2006-
059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
   (Editor's note:  The Personnel Policy Manual for all City employees, adopted
by Ordinance 1993-46, passed April 5, 1993, addresses the subject of the
probationary period of employees (in Section 17 of such Manual), but such
provisions are supplemental to the provisions of this section and not in
derogation thereof.)
240.03   FIRE CAPTAIN.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Fire Captain in the Division
of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services.
   (b)   There shall only be two (2) Fire Captains in the Division.
   (c)   The persons occupying the position of Captain shall fulfill such
duties as directed by the Chief and have the powers provided by duly enacted
City ordinances. In addition, such persons shall perform such duties as
directed by the Mayor in the extended absence or disability of the Chief, or
until a superior position is created.
(Ord. 1981-34. Passed 4-6-81.)
   (d)   Pursuant to Section
13.02 of the City Charter, the position of Fire Captain is hereby declared to
be in the classified service, i.e. subject to the rules and regulations of the
Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 1981-105. Passed 11-16-81; Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.04   FULL TIME FIRE LIEUTENANT.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of six (6) Full Time Fire
Lieutenants in the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services.
(Ord. 1988-70. Passed 5-16-88.)
   (b)   The compensation for such positions shall be as determined by Council.
   (c)   The position of Full Time Fire Lieutenant shall be in the classified
service.
   (d)   The person occupying the position of Full Time Fire Lieutenant shall
fulfill the duties as directed by the Chief and have the powers provided by
duly enacted City ordinances.
(Ord. 1983 -124. Passed 11-7-83; Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.05   FULL TIME FIREFIGHTER/EMT-P.
   (a)   There is hereby established in the Division of Fire and Emergency
Rescue Services the position of Full Time Firefighter/EMT-P.
   (b)   The compensation for such position shall be as determined by Council.
   (c)   The job description and duties of a Firefighter/EMT-P shall be as
specified by the Chief of the Division and/or as designated by resolution or
ordinance.
(Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.06   PART TIME FIREFIGHTER.
   (a)   There is hereby established in the Division of Fire and Emergency
Rescue Services the position of Part Time Firefighter.
   (b)   The compensation for such position shall be as set by ordinance duly
enacted by Council from time to time.
   (c)   The job description and duties of employees in the position shall be
as specified by the Chief of the Division and/or as designated by resolution or
ordinance duly enacted by Council.
(Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.07   FULL TIME ADMINISTRATIVE SECRETARY.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Full Time Administrative
secretary in the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services, effective
January 1, 1988.
   (b)   Such position shall be under the supervision of the Mayor or his or
her designee and shall include such duties as directed by the Chief of Fire and
Emergency Rescue Services.
   (c)   Such position shall be in the classified service.
(Ord. 1987-167. Passed 1-18-88; Ord. 1988-108. Passed 9-12-88; Ord. 2006-059. 
Passed 8-14-06.)
240.08   PART TIME RECORD CUSTODIAN.
   (a)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service two (2)
positions of Part-Time Record Custodians in the Division of Fire and Emergency
Rescue Services.
   (b)   Such positions, appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the supervision
of the Chief of the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services or his or
her designee and shall include such duties as the Chief or his or her designee
shall direct.
   (c)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
   (d)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 1992-31. Passed 3-16-92; Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06; Ord. 2012-102.
Passed 12-17-12.)
240.09   SERVICES TO OTHER FIRE-FIGHTING AGENCIES.
   (a)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60, the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue
Services is hereby authorized, upon the direction of the Chief thereof or, in
his or her absence or disability, upon the direction of the person second in
command or his designee in such Division, to provide fire protection to any
fire-fighting agency within Summit, Medina, Wayne, Stark and Cuyahoga Counties.
   (b)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60, the Division, upon the written
authorization of the Safety Director, the Mayor or the acting Mayor, may
provide fire protection to any fire-fighting agency within the State.
   (c)   Pursuant to Ohio R.C. 9.60 and this section, Council hereby authorizes
the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services, upon the direction of the
Chief of said division, or in his or her absence or disability the officer in
command in accordance with the written departmental procedures, to provide fire
protection on an “automatic response basis” to the City of Akron, Township of
Bath, Township of Copley, Richfield Village, City of Norton and Valley Fire
District, and further to seek such reciprocal assistance on the same basis in
the event of such need.
   (d)   Prior to issuing an order requiring the dispatch and use of personnel
and equipment in the City of Akron, Township of Bath, Township of Copley,
Richfield Village, City of Norton, and Valley Fire District, such officer shall
first assess the safety requirements of the City in the event a need arises
while personnel and equipment from the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue
Services are outside the corporate limits of the City.
   (e)   The Chief of the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services shall
establish policies and procedures with the City of Akron, Township of Bath,
Township of Copley, Richfield Village, City of Norton and Valley Fire District
for areas of coverage by this section and shall secure the approval of the
Mayor or Safety Director of the City prior to the implementation of the same.
   (f)   (1)   The Mayor is hereby authorized to enter into Rapid Intervention
Team agreements with the political jurisdictions set forth under subsection (e)
of this code section and pursuant thereto to enter into approved protocols and/
or future amendments thereto for the implementation of said Rapid Intervention
Team procedures.
      (2)   In this regard, the Chief of the Division of Fire and Emergency
Rescue Services shall make his recommendations to the Mayor relative to the
agreement and protocol and/or any future amendments set forth herein. Copies of
the proposed agreement and protocol to be entered into with the jurisdictions
set forth hereinabove are attached hereto and designated Doc. Nos. 477 and 478
and are made a part of this section as if fully rewritten herein.
   (g)   The Mayor, upon recommendation of the Chief of the Division of Fire
and Emergency Rescue Services, is authorized to enter into an agreement or
agreements to facilitate the City's participation in “Ohio's Emergency Response
Plan” which is designed to provide a method to activate and deliver large
quantities of fire service resources to any area in Ohio once the local mutual
aid systems have been exhausted.
(Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.10   DESIGNATION OF NONSMOKING AREAS BY CHIEF.  (REPEALED)
   (Editor's note:  Section 240.10 was repealed by Ordinance 2007-010, passed
March 19, 2007.)
240.11   EMERGENCY RESCUE SERVICE.
   (a)   The following user fee for Emergency Medical Services (EMS) shall be
charged to all individuals and/or organizations making use of the City's EMS
service as herein provided:
 
   (1)   Medical services.                                             User Fee
                                                                             $800.00
      A.   Advanced Life Support 2                                  per
                                                                             individual
                                                                             $700.00
      B.   Advanced Life Support 1                                  per
                                                                             individual
                                                                             $600.00
      C.   Basic Life Support                                       per
                                                                             individual
      D.   Basic Response with Patient Contact and Treatment but No $200.00
Transport                                                                    per
                                                                             individual
      E.   Basic Response with Patient Contact, No Treatment and No -0-
Transport
   (2)   Transportation Services                                        
      A.   Amount Per Mile to a Medical facility                    $12.00 per
                                                                             mile
 
   (b)   All individuals who receive EMS service listed above, or those
financially responsible for those individuals, will be charged the
corresponding fee for the service provided and shall be responsible for the
same in full with the following exceptions.
      (1)   Individuals who receive a physical evaluation but do not require
individualized treatment or medical transport as a result of an EMS emergency
response or individuals who receive assistance to their bed or chair but do not
require individualized treatment or medical transport as a result of an EMS
emergency response shall not be billed even though an EMS report is generated.
Whenever appropriate, said individual will be requested to sign a medical
refusal.
      (2)   Residents of the City of Fairlawn, their dependents or an overnight
social guest of a City resident and individuals who are non-residents but are
employed within the municipal boundaries of the City of Fairlawn, although
charged fees for the corresponding service provided them, shall only be
responsible for the insured paid amount and not for any co-pay or deductible
amount. Any balance due from these individuals over and above the amount paid
by their respective primary and secondary insurance providers shall be waived.
      (3)   Individuals who are not residents or employed in the City of
Fairlawn but who are in attendance at a Sanctioned Event, as herein defined,
although charged fees for the corresponding service provided them, shall only
be responsible for the insured paid amount and not for any co-pay or deductible
amount. Any balance due from these individuals over and above the amount paid
by their respective primary and secondary insurance providers shall be waived.
         A.   "Sanctioned Event" as used herein shall mean: An activity or
event sponsored by the Copley-Fairlawn School Board; an activity or event
sponsored by a duly certified public, chartered, parochial or private school
within the City; or, an activity or event sponsored by the City of Fairlawn.
"Sanctioned Event" shall also include any service provided pursuant to a mutual
aid or automatic response procedure in existence at the time of such service.
         B.   "Sanctioned Event" shall not mean or include an event or activity
held upon public, chartered, parochial or private school property or city
property which is sponsored by an individual, group or organization other than
the respective School Boards or the City.
   (c)   Mutual Aid or Automatic Response. Mutual Aid or Automatic Response
procedures with the Townships of Bath and Copley and the City of Akron in
existence at the time EMS service is provided shall supersede the provisions of
this Section.
   (d)   Billing and Collection of Fees. The following shall apply to all fees
billed and collected.
      (1)   The Mayor with the consent of Council is hereby authorized and
directed to enter into an agreement with a medical service billing company to
assist the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services in the collection of
the fees as provided herein.
      (2)   Fees due but not paid after reasonable notice and attempts to
collect by the City's billing company shall be referred to the Law Department
for collection.
      (3)   Individuals receiving payment directly from their insurance carrier
shall be responsible to the City for the payment of services provided them.
      (4)   The Director of Public Safety, Director of Finance and the
President of Council by unanimous consent may on a case by case basis reduce
the charges indicated herein based upon the service recipient's insurance
coverage, Medicare and/or Medicaid coverage and/or their overall ability to pay
or for services provided at the request of a neighboring political subdivision
due to extenuating circumstances.
      (5)   All moneys collected for EMS service provided shall be deposited
into the City's general fund.
   (e)   Residents of Nursing Homes. For purposes of this section and for
establishing a permanent residence in the City, an individual is a "resident"
when domiciled in any nursing home within the geographic limits of the City for
a period of six months or as otherwise indicated on the Nursing Home Residency
Form provided by the City of Fairlawn Finance Department.
   (f)   Nursing Home Residency Form. The Administrator or Chief Operating
Officer of any nursing home operating in the City shall complete a Nursing Home
Residency Form supplied by the City for each individual admitted to its
facility. Such form shall require said individual or a member of his or her
immediate family to declare whether that individual is a resident of the City.
The form shall then be forwarded by the Administrator or Chief Operating
Officer to the Finance Director of the City. The death of any individual while
residing in a nursing home located within the City shall be reported to the
Finance Director of the City within fifteen days of such death.
(Ord. 1993-114. Passed 7-19-93; Ord. 1996-60. Passed 6-3-96; Ord. 2006-059. 
Passed 8-14-06; Ord. 2009-048.  Passed 6-15-09; Ord. 2015-059.  Passed 10-5-15;
Ord. 2017-021.  Passed 4-3-17.)
240.12   NONRESIDENT PROTECTION.
   (a)   The provision of fire and emergency rescue service protection to any
county, municipal corporation or township of this State or an adjoining state,
and the provision of complex investigation assistance whenever necessary upon
proper authorization, are hereby approved.
   (b)   Fire protection and emergency rescue service and assistance shall be
extended only upon authorization of the Chief of the Division of Fire and
Emergency Rescue Service, and another officer acting with the authority of the
Chief, as provided by the Rules promulgated by Council taking into account the
following considerations:
      (1)   That such fire and emergency rescue protection may be extended in
times of emergency or disaster only so far as is consistent with the proper
protection of the City and other sections of these Codified Ordinances; and
      (2)   That the availability of fire and rescue equipment and personnel
shall be subject to priority of use within the City.
(Res. 1992-125. Passed 9-14-92; Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
240.13   ACCEPTANCE OF MEDICARE PAYMENTS.
   The Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services EMT Service will accept,
as payment in full, the amount paid by Medicare for patients who are billed by
the City.
(Ord. 1994-11. Passed 2-21-94; Ord. 2006-059.  Passed 8-14-06.)
CHAPTER 242
Department of Public Service
Editor's note:   Pursuant to Section 3.05D.(1) of the City Charter, Ordinance
1986-68, passed April 7, 1986, provided for the establishment of the combined
position of Director of Public Safety/Public Service.  Ordinance 1991-205,
passed December 16, 1991, repealed Ordinance 1986-68, as codified in Section
236.05.
   The City enters into Agreements from time to time with the full-time
employees of the Department of Public Service.  These Agreements provide for
compensation and other incidents of employment.  The provisions of this
chapter, therefore, apply only to those employees and those subjects not
otherwise provided for in such Agreements.  In the event of a conflict between
any of the provisions of this chapter and any of the provisions of such
Agreements, the provisions of the Agreements shall control.  Copies of the
latest relevant legislation and Agreement may be obtained, at cost, from the
Clerk of Council.

242.01   COMPOSITION AND TABLE OF ORGANIZATION; DUTIES; UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   The composition and Table of Organization of the Department of Public
Service shall be as follows:
      (1)   One (1) Service Director
      (2)   One (1) Administrative Secretary
      (3)   Two (2) Deputy Directors of Public Service
      (4)   One (1) Superintendent
      (5)   Three (3) Supervisors
      (6)   Three (3) full-time Mechanics
      (7)   Three (3) full-time Groundskeepers
      (8)   Four (4) full-time Street Repairmen
      (9)   Three (3) full-time Custodians
      (10)   Such other part-time Laborers and Seasonal Laborers as needed
   (b)   The Department of Public Service Table of Organization is only for
illustration purposes and is subject to Councilmanic funding.
   (c)   The positions of Deputy Director of Public Service, Superintendent,
Supervisor, Mechanic, Groundskeeper, Street Repairman, Custodian and
Administrative Secretary shall be full-time positions the compensation for
which shall be subject to Councilmanic approval.
   (d)   The duties of an employee in the Department shall specifically be
those assigned to him by the Director of Public Service.  From time to time and
on an irregular and temporary basis, as the needs of the City may reasonably
require, the Director may require of any employee in the Department to perform
any or all of the duties of any position in addition to or instead of his own.
(Ord. 2006-080A. Passed 10-16-06.)
242.02   CLASSIFICATION OF EMPLOYEES.
   (a)   The positions of Service Director, Street Commissioner, Utilities
Commissioner, Compactor Monitor and part-time Laborer and Seasonal Laborer
shall be designated as unclassified service; the positions of Deputy Director
of Public Service, Superintendent, Supervisor, Mechanic, Groundskeeper, Street
Repairman, Custodian and Administrative Secretary  shall be designated as civil
service.
(Ord. 1994-174. Passed 12-19-94; Ord. 2006-080A.  Passed 10-16-06.)
242.03   STREET COMMISSIONER.
   (a)   The position of Street Commissioner shall be within the Department of
Public Service and may be held in conjunction with another title and/or
position within the Department of Public Service as determined by the Mayor.
   (b)   The duties of the Street Commissioner shall be those as outlined in
the Fairlawn City Charter Section 9.04 and those additional duties as
prescribed by the Mayor.
(Ord. 1975-20. Passed 2-3-75; Ord. 2002-105. Passed 12-16-02; Ord. 2006-080A. 
Passed 10-16-06.)
242.04   UTILITIES COMMISSIONER.
   (a)   The position of Utilities Commissioner shall be within the Department
of Public Service and may be held in conjunction with another title and/or
position within the Department of Public Service as determined by the Mayor.
   (b)   In addition to the duties prescribed by Ordinance, the Utilities
Commissioner shall perform such additional duties as prescribed by the Service
Director.
(Ord. 1984-9. Passed 1-9-84; Ord. 2006-080A.  Passed 10-16-06.)
242.05   COMPACTOR MONITORS.
   (a)   There is hereby established the position of Compactor Monitor in the
unclassified service of the City, in such numbers as Council determines.
   (b)   The compensation for such position shall be determined by Council.
   (c)   The Compactor Monitors shall work under the direction and supervision
of the Director of Public Safety/Public Service or his or her designee and
shall perform such duties as determined by the Director.
   (d)   Such position shall remain until further ordinance of Council.
(Ord. 1987-108. Passed 10-19-87; Ord. 2006-080A.  Passed 10-16-06.)
242.06   MUNICIPAL ENGINEER; INSPECTION FEES.
   (a)   The Municipal Engineer shall perform the duties prescribed by Section
9.03 of the City Charter and such other duties that are prescribed by Council
and shall counsel and advise the Mayor, Council, and its committees, the
Planning Commission and any administrative officer in matters of concern to the
City and within his professional field. The Municipal Engineer shall accept no
private employment for his professional services in the planning or execution
of a project to be executed within the limits of the City wherein he may in any
manner also be called upon for his services as Municipal Engineer, except on
approval thereof by the Municipal Services Committee of Council.
   (b)   Beginning January 1, 2007, the Municipal Engineer shall be paid Ten
Thousand and no/100 dollars ($10,000) per year in equal bi-weekly installments
for his counsel and advice at all regularly scheduled Council legislative
meetings; committee meetings as directed; for his telephone conferences with
administrative officials and members of the general public; for his review of
attachments to legislation submitted to Council; and for his signature approval
on plans, lot splits, subdivisions and developments as required. The Municipal
Engineer shall be subject to Ohio R.C. 145.01 et seq., but shall not be
entitled to any other benefits from the City. For any other services required
of and rendered by the Municipal Engineer, the compensation to be paid to him
shall be such as is established by ordinance after consultation with the Mayor
and the Director of Public Service.
   (c)   In every instance where an inspection or other service of the office
of the Municipal Engineer is required of any private developer of lands, or of
any dedicator of lands to the City, such developer or dedicator shall pay to
the City a fee for such services equal to one hundred ten percent (110%) of the
actual charges of the Municipal Engineer made to the City pursuant to
ordinances pertaining to compensation of the Engineer.
(Ord. 2006-080A.  Passed 10-16-06; Ord. 2006-084.  Passed 10-16-06.)
CHAPTER 244
Division of Parks and Recreation
Editor's note: This chapter, previously a codification of Ordinance 1972-37,
passed February 7, 1972, Ordinance 1972-67, passed March 6, 1972, Ordinance
1974-103, passed May 20, 1974, Ordinance 1977-53, passed June 20, 1977,
Ordinance 1977-63, passed July 18, 1977, Ordinance 1981-41, passed March 16,
1981, Ordinance 1982-44, passed March 1, 1982, Ordinance 1982-50, passed
February 15, 1982, and Ordinance 1982-83, passed April 19, 1982, was repealed
and reenacted in its entirety by Ordinance 1985-30, passed February 4, 1985.
   
244.01   Establishment; purpose.
   
244.015   Mission Statement.
   
244.02   Rules and regulations.
   
244.03   Funds.

244.05   Personnel; specific duties.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Park and Recreation Board - see CHTR. Art. XII
      Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
      Parks and playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 755
      Playgrounds, recreation centers, swimming pools see Ohio R.C. 755.12 et

      Power to regulate vehicle speed in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)

244.01   ESTABLISHMENT; PURPOSE.
   There is hereby established, within the Department of Public Service, a
Division of Parks and Recreation. Such Division shall be a separate and
distinct administrative entity whose purpose shall be to provide for the proper
supervision, development and operation of public parks, playgrounds and other
recreational facilities owned by the City. The Division shall have the
authority to conduct recreational or cultural activities that will enhance the
leisure time of the people in a wholesome and constructive manner.
(Ord. 1985-30. Passed 2-4-85; Ord. 2012-103.  Passed 12-17-12.)
244.015   MISSION STATEMENT.
   The Mission Statement of the Division of Parks and Recreation is hereby
established and set forth as follows:
   The mission of the Parks and Recreation Division is to provide opportunities
to enhance the quality of life for the residential, business and neighboring
communities through a variety of recreational, educational, cultural and
health-related activities and events. The goals of each activity and special
event are to encourage individual, community, economic and environmental
benefits in a safe, meaningful and healthy environment.
(Res. 1996-135. Passed 12-2-96; Ord. 2012-103.  Passed 12-17-12.)
244.02   RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Division of Parks and Recreation shall have the authority to develop
rules and regulations for the government and management thereof, including all
Municipally owned or controlled park or recreational facilities, provided the
same do not contradict the existing rules and regulations of the Park and
Recreation Board. All rules and regulations so developed shall be subject to
the approval of Council. Upon publication, a copy thereof shall be filed in the
office of the Clerk of Council and be in full force and effect.
(Ord. 1985-30. Passed 2-4-85; Ord. 2012-103.  Passed 12-17-12.)
244.03   FUNDS.
   The Division of Parks and Recreation shall plan, promote and operate
recreational facilities and programs with funds appropriated by Council for
such purposes.
(Ord. 1985-30. Passed 2-4-85; Ord. 2012-103.  Passed 12-17-12.)
244.04   COMPOSITION; GENERAL DUTIES.
   (a)   The Division of Parks and Recreation shall be composed of the
following unclassified personnel:
      (1)   Director
      (2)   Part-time Assistant Director
      (3)   Naturalist
      (4)   Two (2) Part-time Park Supervisors
      (5)   Eight (8) Part-time Recreation Leader
      (6)   Part-time Naturalist Assistant
   (b)   The actual number of employees in the Division shall be as determined
by the Director of the Division, subject to the appropriation of funds by
Council for compensation and further subject to the powers of the Mayor as set
forth in Section 3.05C of the City Charter.
   (c)   The duties of the employees in the Division shall specifically be
those assigned to them by the Director of the Division, who will be responsible
for the day-to-day supervision of all employees in the Division.
(Ord. 1999-103A. Passed 11-1-99; Ord. 2012-103.  Passed 12-17-12.)
244.05   PERSONNEL; SPECIFIC DUTIES.
   (a)   Director.
      (1)   The position of Director of the Division of Parks and Recreation
shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor and upon confirmation by Council.
      (2)   The Director shall serve under the direction and supervision of the
Mayor.
      (3)   The duties of the Director include, but are not limited to, the
following:
         A.   Manage and develop uses of the Fairlawn/Kiwanis Community Center;
         B.   Prepare and justify the budget; and control and supervise
Division expenditures;
         C.   Recruit and recommend employment of supplemental personnel needed
for the operation of the Division;
         D.   Ascertain present and future needs for areas, facilities and
programs; and prepare long-term plans to meet these needs, including budgetary
requirements;
         E.   Assist in the improvement and maintenance of all areas and
facilities that are the responsibility of the Division;
         F.   Develop and administer a broad program of recreational activities
for all age groups and interests, while taking into account the resources and
needs of the area;
         G.   Counsel with community groups and individuals to determine
program needs and area and facility requirements and improvements; and
interpret the scope and purpose of present operations and point out
deficiencies and areas in which expansion and improvement are needed;
         H.   Give direction and guidance to departmental staff by defining
standards and principles of operation;
         I.   Confer with other local, regional, State and National
governmental and voluntary agencies concerned with recreation, park,
conservation and other resources to develop cooperation, planning and working
relationships:
         J.   Establish procedures to maintain records of the Division and
provide for a system of reporting and publicizing the work of the Division;
         K.   Prepare an annual report to the Mayor and Council, detailing the
Division's operations and progress for the preceding year;
         L.   Prepare agendas for the Park and Recreation Board meeting and
attend all Board meetings;
         M.   Attend Council meetings and report on the status of the Division;
         N.   Make inspection tours of areas, facilities and equipment to
determine safety, adequacy and the need of maintenance, and report the same to
the Director of Public Service; and
         O.   Perform such other duties as may be required for the safe and
efficient operation of the Division and its facilities.
   (b)   Part-time Assistant Director.
      (l)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service the
position of Part-Time Assistant Director in the Division of Parks and
Recreation.
      (2)   Such position, appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the
supervision of the Director or his or her designee and shall include such
duties as the Director or his or her  designee shall direct including, but are
not limited to, the following:
         A.   Assist in the administration of the Summer Park Program and
supervise staff; order program supplies and equipment and manage inventory
control;
         B.   Plan, develop, coordinate and evaluate summer sports clinics,
children's annual holiday parties, bus trips and volunteer program;
         C.   Assist Director with the management of community special events;
         D.   Be responsible for scheduling the Fairlawn-Kiwanis Community
Center according to developed rental policies and handling contracts;
         E.   Perform administrative duties as required, including department
correspondence, promotional material, program reports, media releases, bulletin
board displays, etc.; and
         F.   Attend and assist the Director at Division events.
      (3)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
      (4)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
   (c)   Naturalist.
      (1)   The full-time position of Naturalist of the Division of Parks and
Recreation shall be appointed by the Mayor.
      (2)   The Naturalist shall serve under the direction and supervision of
the Director.
      (3)   The duties of the Naturalist shall include, but are not limited to,
the following:
         A.   Develop, schedule and implement educational programs pertaining
to nature, environmental issues and natural resources utilizing the Learning
Resource Center and the City of Fairlawn's public parks for a wide range of
interests, abilities and age groups;
         B.   Manage the natural resources of Fort Island Park, including
wildlife, aquatic, forest and plant communities; and develop and maintain the
habitat improvement projects at Fort Island Park as well as assist with park
planning and development;
         C.   Confer with other local, regional, State and National
governmental and voluntary agencies concerned with parks, conservation, natural
resources, and other resources to develop cooperation, planning and working
relationships;
         D.   Manage a team of volunteers from the community to assist with
program preparation, smooth management, operation and staffing of the Learning
Resource Center, or related park activities; and
         E.   Assist the Director and the Assistant Director with other
departmental events.
      (4)   Compensation for this position shall be as provided by Council from
time to time.
   (d)   Part-time Park Supervisor (2).
      (1)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service the
positions of Part-time Park Supervisor in the Division of Parks and Recreation.
      (2)   Such position(s), appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the
supervision of the Director or his or her designee and shall include such
duties as the Director or his or her designee shall direct including, but are
not limited to, the following:
         A.   Aid and assist the Director and the Assistant Director in the
administration of a summer public recreation program and other special event
coordination as needed under the direction and control of the Director;
         B.   Be responsible for the daily operation of the program in his or
her specifically assigned park, as well as reports; and
         C.   Be responsible for supervision of Recreation Leaders in his or
her specifically assigned park.
      (3)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
      (4)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
   (e)   Part-time Recreation Leader (8).
      (1)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service the
positions of Part-Time Recreation Leader in the Division of Parks and
Recreation.
      (2)   Such position(s), appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the
supervision of the Director or his or her designee and shall include such
duties as the Director or his or her designee shall direct including, but are
not limited to, the following:
         A.   Conduct and lead the daily activities of the Summer Park Program;
and
         B.   Be responsible for miscellaneous duties assigned by the Park
Supervisor.
      (3)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
      (4)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
   (f)   Part-time Naturalist Assistant.
      (1)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service the
positions of Part-Time Naturalist Assistant in the Division of Parks and
Recreation.
      (2)   Such position, appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the
supervision of the Director or his or her designee and shall include such
duties as the Director or his or her designee shall direct including, but are
not limited to, the following:
         A.   The primary duty is to aid and assist in the administration of
the Naturalist Programs developed by and under the direction of the Naturalist;
         B.   It shall be the secondary duty to conduct and lead the daily
activities of the Summer Park Program; and
         C.   Be responsible for miscellaneous duties assigned by the
Naturalist or the Park Supervisor.
      (3)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
      (4)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 1999-103A. Passed 11-1-99; Ord. 2004-051.  Passed 7-19-04; Ord. 2012-
103.  Passed 12-17-12.)

CHAPTER 248
Zoning Inspector
Editor's note:  The position of Zoning Inspector has been merged with the
position of Housing and Residential Building Commissioner to form the overall
combined position of Zoning, Housing and Residential Building Commissioner. 
References in this Code to the Residential Building Commissioner, the Housing
Commissioner, the Building Commissioner, the Zoning Inspector, Zoning
Commissioner and the Zoning Administrator all refer to the same individual
holding the title of Zoning, Housing and Residential Building Commissioner.
   Additionally, the Building Commissioner and Zoning Inspector position has
been renamed by Council action to be the Zoning Administrator. (Ord. 2010-059,
Passed 3-7-2011).  Therefore, references throughout these Codified Ordinances
to the Building Commissioner, Zoning Inspector and the Building Commissioner/
Zoning Inspector shall be deemed to mean Zoning Administrator.  See
Chapter 1236 of the Planning and Zoning Code.

250 Employees Generally

classes of Municipal employees, or their representatives, which Agreements
provide for compensation and other incidents of employment.  The provisions of
this chapter, therefore, apply only to those employees and those subjects not
otherwise provided for in such Agreements.  In the event of a conflict between

chapter, the provisions of the Agreements shall control.  Copies of the latest

for all City employees.  Ordinance 1999-77, passed July 12, 1999, adopted a
newly revised Employee Handbook of 1999.  Ordinance 2017-017, passed April 3,
2017, adopted the renamed Full-time Employees Handbook and Ordinance 2017-018,
passed April 3, 2017, adopted the renamed Part-time Employees Handbook. In the
event of a conflict between any of the provisions of this chapter and any of
the provisions of such Manual, the provisions of the Manual shall control. 
Copies of Ordinance 2017-017 and Ordinance 2017-018 and of such Manual may be
obtained, at cost, from the Clerk of Council.

250.07   REIMBURSEMENT FOR LITIGATION, ETC.
   Except as otherwise provided by ordinance, no compensation shall be paid to
any elected or appointed officer of the City, or to any member of any City
board beyond that provided for by the terms of employment or service or
commission, or to any employee of the City, for his attendance in his official
capacity at any trial or hearing in any court or before any municipal, State or
Federal board, committee or commission, where such appearance is required by
reason of the official position or employment of such person by the City.
However, such official, board member or employee may retain ordinary witness
fees paid to him by the clerk of any court by reason of such proceedings and
the City shall reimburse such official, board member or employee for his
ordinary and necessary expenses incurred in connection with such appearance.
(Ord. 1972-165. Passed 12-18-72; Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)
250.08   BONDS.
   (a)   Before entering upon the discharge of his duties, each officer and
employee herein named shall execute a bond in favor of the City, conditioned
upon the faithful discharge of such duties, which bond shall be subject to the
approval of the Director of Law and which bond shall be in the amount set forth
opposite the office or position set forth below:
      Director of Finance             $50,000
      Tax Administrator             $50,000
      Clerk of Mayor's Court          $50,000
      All other officers and employees   $10,000 blanket bond
   (b)   The premium for each and every bond required by subsection (a) hereof
shall be paid by the
City.
(Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)

   (Editor’s note: The Personnel Policy Manual for city employees, originally

250.13   LEGAL DEFENSE OF OFFICIALS AND OFFICERS.
   (a)   The City hereby assumes responsibility for providing the legal defense
of any lawsuit against any duly elected official and any duly appointed officer
of the City, both individually and as such official or officer, alleged to have
arisen out of any act or failure to act within the scope of the regular
official duties of such official or officer, provided that such act or failure
to act was not malicious, motivated for private gain, and did not constitute
misfeasance, malfeasance or nonfeasance.
   (b)   Members of Council, when acting in good faith, are hereby declared
exempt from individual liability for the exercise of their legislative
discretion in voting, as members of Council, for or against any proposed
legislation before them for consideration.
   (c)   The City shall hold any such official or officer harmless from cost or
liability arising out of the good faith performance of official duties.
(Ord. 1982-24. Passed 2-1-82; Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)
250.14   CLASSIFIED AND UNCLASSIFIED POSITIONS.
   (a)   Pursuant to Section 13.02 of the City Charter, the following job
classifications are hereby declared to be in the classified service, i.e.
subject to the rules and regulations of the Civil Service Commission:
      (1)   Full-time members of the Division of Police, excluding the Chief of
Police;
      (2)   Full-time employees of the Department of Public Service;
      (3)   The Clerk-Typist-Bookkeeper-Office Manager; and
      (4)   The Clerk-Bookkeeping Machine Operator.
      (5)   Intermittent Fire, Police and Service Department employees.
(Ord. 1990-79. Passed 5-7-90; Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)
   (b)   No elected official or department head appointed by the Mayor, such as
the Street Commissioner, the Zoning Inspector, the Building Commissioner, the
Assistant Finance Director, the Tax Administrator, the Recreation Director, the
Law Director, the City Engineer, the Secretary to the Mayor and appointed board
or commission members, shall be in the classified service.
   (c)   Council shall designate in the ordinance creating the position whether
or not every new job classification created hereafter is within the classified
service.
(Ord. 1979-46. Passed 7-9-79; Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)

250.19   PART-TIME GENERAL SECRETARY.
   (a)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service the position
of Part-Time General Secretary in the Administration offices.
   (b)   Such position, appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the supervision
of the Mayor's Executive Assistant or his or her designee and shall include
such duties as the Executive Assistant or his or her designee shall direct.
   (c)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
   (d)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 1985-49. Passed 3-18-85; Ord. 2012-104. Passed 12-17-12; Ord. 2017-012.
Passed 4-3-17.)
250.20   INTERMITTENT EMPLOYEE.
   (a)   There is hereby established the job classification of "intermittent
employee" within the City. "Intermittent employee" means any person who has
taken and passed a competitive exam for a classified position and works on an
irregular schedule which is not predictable, but is based on and determined by
the fluctuating demands of the position held.
   (b)   The job classification of intermittent employee shall be a classified
position with civil service protection.
(Ord. 1990-79. Passed 5-7-90; Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)
250.21   RETIREMENT CONTRIBUTION PICK-UP PLAN.
   (a)   There is hereby adopted a retirement system contribution plan for
full-time employees of the Department of Public Service, the Police Division,
and the Division of Fire and Emergency Rescue Services, general employees and
elected officials, whereby an employee's contribution will be made by the
employer in lieu of the contribution made by the employee by using before-tax
compensation earned by the employee.
   (b)   Consistent with the terms of all public retirement systems of the
State, no employee covered by the plan shall have the option of receiving any
of his or her contributions directly from the employer.
   (c)   Payroll tax calculation for Federal and State taxes and other
applicable payroll deductions shall be made after any such contribution is made
on behalf of an employee.
(Ord. 1990-185. Passed 12-3-90;  Ord. 1991-15(A). Passed 1-7-91; Ord. 2004-
003.  Passed 2-23-04; Ord. 2004-040.  Passed 5-17-04; Ord. 2004-041.  Passed 5-
17-04; Ord. 2017-012. Passed 4-3-17.)
   (Editor’s note: The Personnel Policy Manual for city employees, originally
adopted by Ordinance 1993-46, passed April 3, 1993, and which has been amended
from time to time and renamed Full-time Employees Handbook and Part-time
Employees Handbook and which may continue to be amended from time to time,
addresses personnel subjects, but such provisions are supplemental to the
provisions of this section and not in derogation thereof.)
250.22   PART-TIME COMPUTER SPECIALIST.
   (a)   There is hereby established in the unclassified service the position
of Part-Time Computer Specialist in the Information Services Department.
   (b)   Such position, appointed by the Mayor, shall be under the supervision
of the Director of Information Services or his or her designee and shall
include such duties as the Director or his or her designee shall direct.
   (c)   Employee(s) in this position shall work on average less than thirty
(30) hours per week. This position shall not qualify for any fringe benefits,
including, but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation leave or
holiday leave.
   (d)   Compensation shall be as provided by Council from time to time.
(Ord. 2004-008.  Passed 2-23-04; Ord. 2012-104. Passed 12-17-12; Ord. 2017-012.
Passed 4-3-17.)
CHAPTER 252
Sale, Lease or Other Disposition of City Owned Lands
   
252.01   Procedures.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Procedures of Council - see ADM.
220.02
252.01   PROCEDURES.
   (a)   A sale negotiated by the Mayor or his designee at a fixed price to a
named grantee may be consummated upon approval of Council.  In its approval,
Council shall find that the property in question is no longer needed for
municipal purposes.
   (b)   The authorization for such sale shall be made by a two-thirds (2/3)
vote of the members of Council.
   (c)   An appraisal of the subject property shall be obtained from a
qualified appraiser, and the sale shall be made at a price no less than the
City's appraisal as determined by an appraiser selected by the Administration.
   (d)   The Administration may negotiate appropriate fees for sale, lease or
other disposition of such City owned lands which fees shall include, but not be
limited to: sales commissions, appraisal fees, closing costs, and other usual,
customary and necessary expenses.
(Ord. 2002-072A. Passed 9-9-02.)

CHAPTER 270 Boards and Commissions Generally
   
270.01   Secretaries; duties.
   
270.02   Contract Secretaries; Sessions Clerk for Mayor's Court.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Establishment - see CHTR. Secs.
3.05E.,
5.01
      Compensation and bonds - see CHTR. Sec.
4.14
      Communications between Council and boards and commissions - see CHTR.
Sec.
17.06
270.01   SECRETARIES; DUTIES.
   (a)   Each commission and board created by the City Charter or by action of
Council or otherwise required by law to organize in the City shall elect and/or
select a secretary for such commission or board.
   (b)   The duties of such secretaries shall be to keep accurate and concise
notes of all actions of such commissions or boards, to transcribe such notes
and to distribute such notes or minutes of meetings of such commissions or
boards to the Mayor and each member of Council, individually, not later than
seven (7) days after the date of each meeting or conference.
   (c)   In order to facilitate such duties each such secretary shall have the
right to use the services of the City Secretary and the duplicating equipment
and supplies of the City.
   (d)   Copies of this section shall be certified and forwarded to the
chairmen and secretaries of each commission and board and shall be read into
the minutes of the meetings thereof.
(Ord. 1965-23. Passed 2-1-65.)
270.02   CONTRACT SECRETARIES; SESSIONS CLERK FOR MAYOR'S COURT.
   (a)   There is hereby recognized the position of Contract Secretary and
hereby created the position of Sessions Clerk for the Mayor's Court of the City
of Fairlawn.  The duties of the Sessions Clerk shall be those prescribed by the
Mayor, and all other provisions of this section shall apply to the position of
Sessions Clerk except for compensation as set forth in subsection (e) hereof.
   (b)   The duties of each Contract Secretary shall be to take minutes at
official meetings of Council, boards and commissions and other sanctioned
meetings requiring an official record, to transcribe the minutes, to prepare
required copies and to distribute such copies.
   (c)   The duly elected, qualified and acting chairman of each City board or
commission shall have supervisory responsibility over the Contract Secretary
working for that body.  In the case of Council, the President of Council shall
have supervisory responsibility and in all other situations requiring
employment of a Contract Secretary the Mayor shall have supervisory
responsibility.
   (d)   Contract Secretaries shall be independent contractors, selected
outside of civil service rules and regulations by the supervisory authority.
   (e)   Contract Secretaries shall be compensated at the following rates, per
hour or part thereof, for attendance at meetings:
         $10.00      0 to 1 year
           $12.00      1 to 2 years
         $15.00      over 2 years
   In addition, Contract Secretaries shall be compensated at a flat rate of
forty-five dollars ($45.00) for transcribing and distributing minutes for a
duration of two (2) hours or less, and a flat rate of seventy-five dollars
($75.00) for transcribing and distributing minutes for a duration of over two
(2) hours. Contract Secretaries shall receive no other compensation, such as
fringe benefits, except as set forth in this section.  Any employee under this
section shall receive credit or deduction for the Public Employees Retirement
System or other retirement program.
   (f)   The payment of Contract Secretaries shall be by official City checks
payable within thirty (30) days after service is rendered.
   (g)   Contract Secretaries shall transcribe the minutes and distribute
copies on their own time, it having been determined that the compensation for
each meeting attended includes such services.
   (h)   Contract Secretaries may use City typewriters, paper and copying
machines for preparing and duplicating transcribed minutes.
   (i)   Any change in the compensation of Contract Secretaries shall be
initiated by the Mayor or any member of Council and shall require Councilmanic
action and approval after review and recommendation by the Finance Committee of
Council.
(Ord. 1999-036. Passed 4-5-99.)

Parks and Recreation as to the goals, policies and direction of the Division,
as developed by the Director or as otherwise set forth in the City Charter.

278.01   ESTABLISHMENT.
   Pursuant to the City Charter and the statutes of the State, there is hereby
established a Civil Service Commission.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.02   MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENTS.
   The Civil Service Commission established herein shall consist of three
electors of the Municipality not holding other office in the Municipality, to
be appointed by the Mayor subject to confirmation by the affirmative vote of
five or more members of Council.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.03   TERMS OF ORIGINAL APPOINTEES.
   The original appointments to the Civil Service Commission shall run from the
effective date of the resolution confirming such appointments and shall expire
as set forth below:
   (a)   The first appointment shall expire December 31, 1977.
   (b)   The second appointment shall expire December 31, 1979.
   (c)   The third appointment shall expire December 31, 1981.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.04   TERMS OF SUBSEQUENT APPOINTEES.
   All appointments, subsequent to the original appointments, shall be for
terms of six years, except for a vacancy occurring during the term of any
member that shall be filled for the unexpired term pursuant to Section 278. 02.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.05   COMPENSATION.
   All members of the Civil Service Commission shall serve without
compensation.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.06   MEETINGS.
   The Civil Service Commission shall meet within fifteen days after the
effective date of the confirmation of the third member, and regularly
thereafter, as required to discharge the duties set forth herein, by the
Charter, by other ordinances of the City or by statutes of the State.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.07   OFFICERS.
   The Civil Service Commission shall elect from its members at its first
meeting and at a meeting in January and each succeeding year hereafter, a
Chairman, Vice-Chairman and Secretary.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.08   QUORUM; VOTING.
   A majority of the members of the Civil Service Commission shall constitute a
quorum and the affirmative vote of a majority of the members of the Commission
shall be necessary for any official action.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.09   RULES AND REGULATIONS; JOURNAL OF PROCEEDINGS.
   The Civil Service Commission shall adopt its own rules and regulations and
shall keep a complete journal of proceedings, showing the vote of each member
on every question, which journal shall be open for public inspection at all
times during the scheduled hours of the Municipal offices or by appointment.
(Ord. 1976-43. Passed 4-5-76.)
278.10   RECORDING SECRETARY. (REPEALED)
   (Editor's note: Section 278.10 was repealed by implication by Ordinance
1979-22, passed April 2, 1979. See Section
278.12.)
278.11   FUNDING FOR GENERAL ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSE.
   (a)   The Civil Service Commission shall submit a preliminary budget for the
following calendar year to the Finance Committee of Council not later than June
l of each year for anticipated administrative expenses.
   (b)   Council shall include in the preliminary budget approved in July and
the operating appropriation approved in January an amount for the
administrative operation of the Commission.
   (c)   The Finance Director shall cause to be issued the usual vouchers and/
or warrants upon authorization of the Commission provided there is a sufficient
balance remaining appropriated in the General Account earmarked for the
Commission.
   (d)   Supplemental appropriation shall be submitted to Council for approval.
(Ord. 1979-25. Passed 4-16-79.)
278.12   SECRETARY.
   (a)   The position of Secretary to the Civil Service Commission is hereby
created.
   (b)   The Secretary to the Civil Service Commission shall be a part-time
position not in the classified service.
   (c)   The duties of the Secretary shall be as determined by the Commission.
   (d)   The Secretary shall be under the direct supervision of the Commission.
   (e)   The Secretary shall be regularly compensated at a rate determined by
Council, by ordinance, from time to time. In addition thereto, the Secretary
shall be compensated at a rate determined by Council for taking and
transcribing minutes and for preparation of the same for distribution, for time
involved in examination procedures and certification of payrolls and for any
other service directed by the Commission.
   (f)   Payment to the Secretary shall be by official City checks payable from
the Civil Service Commission budget within thirty days after service is
rendered.
   (g)   Any change in the compensation of the Secretary shall be initiated by
the Mayor or any member of Council and shall require Councilmanic action and
approval after review and recommendation by the Finance Committee of Council.
   (h)   The Secretary shall not qualify for any fringe benefits, including,
but not limited to, hospitalization, sick leave, vacation and holidays. The
Secretary shall receive credit or deduction for the Public Employees Retirement
System or other retirement programs.
(Ord. 1980-60. Passed 6-16-80; Ord. 1982-38. Passed 2-1-82; Ord. 1982-183.
Passed 1-6-82; Ord. 1982-197. Passed 12-20-82; Ord. 1984-169. Passed 11-5-84;
Ord. 1985-15. Passed 1-7-85; Ord. 1985-16. Passed 1-7-85; Ord. 1982-21(S).
Passed 3-2-92.)

281.01   CREATION AND ESTABLISHMENT OF A REAL PROPERTY MAINTENANCE BOARD.
   (a)   There is hereby created and established a Real Property Maintenance
Board for the City of Fairlawn, which may hereafter be referred to as the
“Board.”
(Ord. 2005-037.  Passed 5-2-05; Ord. 2015-021. Passed 5-4-15.)
281.02   JURISDICTION.
   (a)   The Board shall function in place of and have all authority and
responsibility conferred upon the City Forestry Board (Ordinance 2005-15) and
provided in Section
283.01 et seq. and the Board of Motor Vehicle Evaluation (Ordinance 2005-029A)
and provided in Fairlawn City Code Section
660.07 et seq.
   (b)   The Board shall hear appeals of the decision of the Service Director
as provided in Fairlawn City Code Section
678.06 and the Zoning Inspector as provided in Fairlawn City Code Section
660.07 and the Residential Chief Building Official as provided in Fairlawn City
Code Sections
1516.01 through
1516.07 and
1566.01 through
1566.07 and shall conduct such other hearings and business and have such other
authority as conferred by Council and directed by the Mayor.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.03   COMPOSITION AND TERM.
   (a)   The Board shall consist of five members and one alternate member all
of whom must be electors of the City.  Board members shall be appointed by the
Mayor with confirmation by Council.
   (b)   When the initial term of office expires, each new Board appointment is
for a term of five years, beginning on January 2nd of each respective calendar
year.
   (c)   Should a Board member resign or be removed from the Board, a successor
shall be appointed by the appropriate appointing authority and shall serve for
the remainder of the unexpired term.
   (d)   Board members shall serve, without compensation, at the pleasure of
the appointing authority.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.04   ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   At the first meeting of each calendar year, the Board shall elect a
chairperson, a vice-chairperson, and secretary from the Board membership.
   (b)   The Board shall adopt rules and regulations governing its procedures.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.05   MEETINGS.
   The Board shall regularly meet as needed in Fairlawn Council Chambers and
shall conduct such business as is properly scheduled to be heard according to
the rules and regulations set forth herein.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.06   SPECIAL MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Chairperson or Vice-Chairperson may call a special meeting on such
day and time as convenient. Such meetings may be called in order to handle
business previously scheduled but unable to be heard, unfinished business from
a prior meeting which necessitates a decision or a judgment of the Board, or to
facilitate certain applicants where hardship, prior delays, or other unusual
circumstances warrant it.
   (b)   A special meeting called for the purpose described above shall be
conducted in the same manner as a regular meeting. When a special meeting is
called, only the item(s) on the agenda may be heard at that meeting.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.07   QUORUM.
   (a)   In order for the Board to conduct any business, a quorum must be
present. Three members present constitute a quorum. If a member cannot attend a
meeting for any reason other than an emergency, said member must notify the
Chairperson and the Chairperson must notify the Board's recording secretary by
the Friday before the scheduled meeting.
   (b)   The alternate member shall sit in place of an absent member and shall
have the authority to vote on issues before the Board only when there is an
absent member. However, the alternate member shall not hold a Board office and
shall not assume the duties of any officer when sitting in the absence of such
officer.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.08   ORDER OF BUSINESS.
   The Chairperson, or in his/her absence, the Vice-Chairperson, shall preside
over each meeting of the Board.
   (a)   Attendance shall be taken and recorded in the minutes.
   (b)   The Chairperson shall determine if a quorum is present.  If not, the
meeting shall adjourn.
   (c)   Minutes of the previous meeting shall be reviewed and amended if
necessary, then approved or disapproved by majority vote of the members
present.
   (d)   All those matters properly scheduled on the agenda will be heard in
the following order:
      (1)   Old business;
      (2)   New business;
      (3)   Other business.
   (e)   Adjournment.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.09   VOTES REQUIRED TO UPHOLD AN ORDER OF REMOVAL.
   (a)   To uphold the City's Order of Removal, a minimum of three affirmative
votes is required.
   (b)   Affirmative votes of two or less shall cause the Order of Removal to
be rejected.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.10   PROCEDURE TO INITIATE ACTION BY THE BOARD.
   (a)   A person who appeals any notice or order of the relevant City Code
Sections shall file a written request for a hearing and shall set forth the
name, address and telephone number of the appellant and a brief statement of
the basis for the appeal and the relief requested. Requests shall be filed
within ten days after the day the notice or order is served and shall be
accompanied by a nonrefundable deposit of fifteen dollars ($15.00) for
residential appeals, or thirty dollars ($30.00) if it is an appeal by a
business.
   (b)   Upon receipt of the request, the Board shall set a time and place for
a hearing before the Board. The hearing shall be held within a reasonable time
after an appeal has been filed.
   (c)   The appellant shall be given a hearing to show cause why the notice
and order should be modified or dismissed, or why a variance should be granted.
The failure of the appellant or his or her representative to appear and present
their position at the hearing shall result in dismissal of the request.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.11   PROCEDURES.
   If the Board is unable to reach an agreement upon a procedure for the Board,
the Board's legal advisor shall use Robert's Rules of Order to formulate the
procedure to be used.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.12   CONDUCT OF MEETINGS.
   The Board shall hear sworn testimony from the Residential Chief Building
Official or other representative(s) of the City, the appellant, and any other
individual offering relevant testimony, and shall permit cross-examination
thereof.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
281.13   DECISION OF BOARD.
   The Board shall issue findings of fact and its decision may affirm, reverse,
modify, dismiss, or grant a variance from the notice and order by a majority
vote of the members of the Board who are present at the hearing. The appellant,
the Law Director and the Residential Chief Building Official shall be notified
in writing of the findings of the Board.
(Ord. 2016-031.  Passed 4-18-16.)
CHAPTER 282
