814.01   PURPOSE AND FINDINGS.
   (a)   Purpose. That the purpose of this chapter is to establish reasonable
and uniform regulations to minimize and control the negative effects of adult
amusement arcades within the City in order to promote the health, safety and
welfare of the citizens of the City. It is not the purpose or intent of this
chapter to restrict or deny access to recreational and skilled-based adult
amusement machines.
   (b)   Findings. The State of Ohio currently allows certain games of skill
while games of chance are deemed illegal. It is possible that games of skill
operated electronically, may easily be altered to illegal games of chance.
Further, that the City has a duty to its citizens to require businesses open to
the public operate within the bounds of the law; to maintain safe ingress and
egress; and to maintain adequate security where a considerable volume of cash
is transacted.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.02   DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   As used in this chapter, except where the context clearly indicates a
different meaning:
      “Adult amusement arcade” means a self contained building or structure,
which is either owner occupied or leased in which seventy-five percent (75%) of
the business's usable floor area is used for the placement of skill-based adult
amusement devices.
      “Adult amusement device” means any skill-based adult device, machine or
instrument legally operable within the State of Ohio which either may be
activated for play by a third party, person or device, or upon the insertion of
paper money, a coin, token, slug, or card, operates or may be operated as a
game, contest, test of skill or other adult amusement of any kind for which a
prize, reward, money or anything of value may be received. “Adult amusement
device” does not include vending machines.
      “Game machine” means any skill-based adult amusement device.
      “Good moral character” means not having been convicted of a crime
involving moral turpitude within five (5) years next preceding the date of the
application.
      “Malfunction” means failure to operate in accordance with design.
      “Moral turpitude” means a conviction for a theft offense, fraud,
falsification, drug offense, sex offense, an offense involving gambling or a
felony.
      “Operator” means any individual, corporation or other entity conducting
the business of an adult amusement arcade.
      “Owner” means any individual, corporation or other entity owning title to
any adult amusement device or the real property at which an adult amusement
arcade is operated.
      “Playing area” means that portion of the premises where the primary use
is for customer play on adult amusement devices.
      “Skill-based adult amusement device” means a skill-based adult amusement
device or skill- based adult amusement machine, such as a mechanical,
electronic, video, or digital device or machine, whether or not the skill-based
adult amusement device requires payment for use through a coin or bill
validator or other payment of consideration or value to participate in the
device's offering or to activate the device, provided that all of the following
apply:
      (1)   The device involves a task, game, play, contest, competition or
tournament in which the player actively participates in the task, game, play,
contest, competition or tournament.
      (2)   The outcome of an individual's play and participation is not
determined largely or wholly by chance. For purposes of this chapter, “largely
or wholly” means at least by fifty-one percent (51%).
      (3)   The outcome of play during a game is controlled only by the person
actively participating in the game.
      (4)   The device only charges one (1) price to play a task, game, play,
contest, competition or tournament.
         A.   All of the following apply to any device that is operated as
described in this section:
            1.   As used in this section, “task,” “game” and “play” mean one
(1) event from the initial activation of the device until the results of play
are determined without payment of additional consideration. An individual
utilizing a device that involves a single task, game, play, contest,
competition or tournament may be awarded prizes based on the results of play;
the prizes or rewards shall be established prior to the individual placing a
wager; and, the individual shall be aware of what prize or reward will occur
prior to the start of play.
            2.   Advance play for a single task, game, play, contest,
competition or tournament participation may be purchased. The cost of the
contest, competition or tournament participation may be greater than a single
non- contest, competition or tournament play.
            3.   To the extent that the device is used in a contest,
competition or tournament, that contest, competition or tournament has a
defined starting and ending
         date and is open to participants in competition for scoring and
ranking results toward the awarding of prizes without payment of additional
consideration.
            4.   No device shall have a guessing game at the end of a
successfully completed task, game, play, contest, competition or tournament.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.03   OPERATION; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   (a)   No individual, corporation or other entity shall be an operator of an
adult amusement arcade at any place of business unless such operator holds a
valid adult amusement arcade license for the place of business where such adult
amusement arcade is operated.
   (b)   No individual, corporation or other entity shall permit or cause to be
permitted any adult amusement device to be operated, placed into operation,
moved onto the area of play or played without a current and valid license for
that device displayed thereon.
   (c)   No individual, corporation or other entity shall play any adult
amusement device unless it is validly licensed by the City.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.04   APPLICATION INFORMATION.
   (a)   The original and renewal application for an adult amusement arcade
license and the license for each skill-based adult amusement device shall be
upon a form prescribed by the Director of Public Safety and shall set forth
therein information such as the name and address of the operator; the address
of the place of business which is to be the licensed adult amusement arcade;
the name and address of the owner of the real property at which the business is
located; the year for which the license is sought; the serial number of skill-
based adult amusement devices located at such place of business; the name and
address of the owner of each device; a detailed explanation of the device's
operation; applicable software license authorization, player skills and
training required qualifying each machine as a game of skill; and such other
information as the Director of Public Safety reasonably requires. The
application shall be signed by the operator in whose name the City licenses are
to be issued as well as the owner of the real property.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.05   CORPORATIONS, TRUSTS, AND PARTNERSHIPS.
   (a)   If the operator filing the application for a license under this
chapter is a corporation or limited liability company the application shall
list the names and addresses of all officers and directors and any individual,
corporation or other entity owning twenty-five percent (25%) or more of the
issued and outstanding shares or units of every class of stock or units of such
corporation.
   (b)   If the operator filing the application for a license is a partnership
or limited liability partnership the application shall list the names and
addresses of all partners.
   (c)   If the operator filing the application for a license is a trust, the
application shall list the names and addresses of all trustees and/or co-
trustees.
   (d)   The listing required of any corporation, trust, partnership or other
entity shall be repeated and further repeated for any corporation, trust,
partnership or other entity who or which appears as a shareholder, unit owner,
trustee, co-trustee or partner on the application.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.06   AFFIDAVIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   The application for a license under this chapter shall be submitted on
forms provided by the Director of Public Safety and be accompanied by an
affidavit attesting that the operator and all employees and agents of the
operation have not been convicted of a crime of moral turpitude and to the
truth of the matters set forth in such application. No person shall swear
falsely in any affidavit required to be filed under this section.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.07   LICENSE ISSUANCE; EFFECTIVE PERIOD; FEE.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety is hereby authorized to issue adult
amusement arcade licenses and adult amusement device licenses, in such form as
he or she determines to be appropriate, for a period of up to one (1) year,
upon satisfaction of all of the following conditions:
      (1)   The operator of the adult amusement arcade has properly filed the
application required by this chapter. The applicant and the owners of the
skill-based adult amusement devices and the real property owner shall sign the
application;
      (2)   A fee of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) per adult amusement
arcade location per year has been paid;
      (3)   A fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per adult amusement device
per month has been paid in advance annually;
      (4)   The operator or any employee of the operator has not been convicted
of a crime of moral turpitude within the past five (5) years;
      (5)   The Director of Public Safety has determined that no other
reasonable cause exists to deny the issuance of such license;
      (6)   Compliance with Section
814.09;
      (7)   License fees are non-refundable except upon approval by this
Council.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.08   LICENSE ADMINISTRATION.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the Director of Public Safety or his designee
to administer the licensing regulations of this chapter.
   (b)   The Director of Public Safety or his designee is hereby empowered to
adopt and enforce such rules and regulations relating to any matter or thing
pertaining to the issuance, administration, and enforcement of this chapter.
   (c)   The burden shall rest on the owner, applicant, operator and/or agent
of the operator, owner or applicant to timely produce the complete, accurate
and true records, documents, programs source codes or other data or objects
necessary to substantiate the licensing requirements of this chapter. Absent
such substantiation, the decision of the Director of Public Safety shall be
final subject to Section
814.15.
   (d)   A license shall be issued within forty-five (45) days of receipt of
the completed application and compliance with this chapter.
   (e)   No adult arcade license shall be issued until all individual adult
amusement devices are licensed.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.09   SUBMISSION OF SOURCE CODE FOR APPROVAL.
   (a)   Each applicant, within forty-five (45) days of submitting an
application for an adult amusement arcade license, shall submit to the Director
of Public Safety:
      (1)   A written report prepared by an independent laboratory satisfactory
to the Director of Public Safety stating that the specific adult amusement
device, including but not limited to the source code, has been tested and
examined under the requirements of the Ohio Revised Code and this chapter and
the specific adult amusement device is largely or wholly a game of skill.
      (2)   A report must be prepared for each adult amusement device to be
licensed.
      (3)   An exact and sealed copy of the source code for each adult
amusement device shall accompany the report. Such sealed code shall be deemed
proprietary and shall be held by the Director of Public Safety or his designee
until the license is expired, revoked, or there are reasonable grounds to
believe a violation of this chapter has occurred. If reasonable grounds exist,
the sealed source code will be provided to law enforcement for investigation.
Otherwise, the source code will be returned to the licensee.
   (b)   The Director of Public Safety shall provide the names of at least two
(2) laboratories deemed satisfactory for testing and examination.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.10   LICENSE VALIDITY AND DISPLAY.
   (a)   Each license under this chapter shall be valid for only so long as the
adult amusement arcade is operated by the operator listed on such license, at
the place of business listed thereon. Each skill-based adult amusement device
shall be valid for operation or use only so long as the skill-based adult
amusement device has displayed on it a current license, or until the license is
revoked by the City or until such devices are determined to be games of chance
or otherwise deemed illegal by the State of Ohio or a court of competent
jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.11   OPERATION OF ADULT ARCADE.
   (a)   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be permitted on
the premises.
   (b)   No doors shall be locked preventing ingress or egress by members of
the public while patrons are on the premises.
   (c)   The operator shall adopt and enforce a no loitering policy on the
premises.
   (d)   The premises of every adult amusement arcade shall be equipped with
exterior lighting of sufficient intensity to illuminate every means of ingess
and egress and adjacent parking areas.
   (e)   Each adult arcade shall be maintained so that it is handicap
accessible throughout.
   (f)   Subject to (g) below each adult arcade shall be operated with a glass
storefront allowing full visibility at the sidewalk or right-of-way from the
front through the playing area to the rear of the facility, exclusive of
restrooms. No adult amusement devices shall be placed in restrooms.
   (g)   Storefront windows shall be opaquely shaded to a height of four (4)
feet above the ground and thereafter shall be clear glass, free of tint and
without any covering to permit full visibility from the outside as required in
(f) above.
   (h)   Beer, wine or alcoholic beverages shall not be served anywhere in or
on the premises.
   (i)   The operator shall maintain a record of each adult amusement device
taken out of play for any reason, including but not limited to, device
malfunction. The record shall include, but not be limited to the following:
name of operator taking the device out of play; name and address of player who
last played; the amount reflected as won but not paid or lost by the last
person who played that device; a description of the malfunction; a description
of how the adult amusement device was designed to operate; time and date of
removal from play; make, model and serial number of the adult amusement device.
Said record shall be maintained on the premises for at least two (2) years from
date of removal. Further, the record shall be available for inspection to the
Director of Public Safety, his agents and designees during regular business
hours.
   (j)   No adult arcade shall operate during the hours of 1:00 a.m. to 6:00
a.m.
   (k)   Each operator shall maintain a record of the full name, address,
telephone number, date, tax identification number and gross value amount for
each player receiving consideration or anything of value exceeding two hundred
dollars ($200.00). This record shall be filed with the Director of Finance for
the City of Fairlawn at least quarterly. Further, such record shall be
available for inspection to the Director of Public Safety, his agents and
designees during regular business hours for a period of two (2) years.
   (l)   Each operator shall clearly post in a conspicuous place all
circumstances in which a player may not “cash out”, be reimbursed or receive a
cash payment for the value of winnings, credits, rewards or prepayments.
   (m)   Each operator, employee and agent thereof shall wear a full name
identification nameplate during working hours.
   (n)   All on premises food service shall comply with State and local health
regulations.
   (o)   Each operator shall conspicuously display by posting with each skill-
based adult amusement device the established prize or reward for each play.
This information shall be posted so that the player can observe it prior to and
during play.
   (p)   Each operator shall make available and have on display forms as
prescribed by the Director of Public Safety for the recovery of losses pursuant
to Ohio R.C. Chapter 3763.
   (q)   No weapons, firearms or dangerous ordnance are permitted on the
premises.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.12   LICENSE REVOCATION.
   (a)   It shall be cause for revocation of any license required under this
chapter, by the issuing authority, or for non-renewal of such license, for an
operator or operator's officers, directors, agents or employees, trustee,
twenty-five percent (25%) of the shareholders of an operator or any other
person to:
      (1)   Operate an adult amusement arcade without a valid license;
      (2)   Operate or permit to be operated an adult amusement device without
a valid license for that device;
      (3)   Fail to display any license required by this chapter;
      (4)   Provide any false or misleading information in the material
submitted during the application process;
      (5)   Permit any violation of an ordinance or regulation of the City; a
regulation of the County, including but not limited to rules of the Summit
County Department of Health; or a statute of the State or Federal government
any for which a criminal penalty may be invoked, to take place at any adult
amusement arcade operated by such operator; or
      (6)   Knowingly allow gambling on the premises;
      (7)   Transfer or alter any license issued under this chapter;
      (8)   Failure to comply with any provision of this chapter;
      (9)   Be convicted of a crime involving moral turpitude.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.13   REVOCATION PROCESS.
   (a)   The Director of Public Safety shall notify the licensee in writing, at
the address of the adult amusement arcade, of the reason for revocation.
Service shall be made by certified first class mail with proof of service or
personally.
   (b)   When the City revokes a license, the licensee shall not be issued
another license for one (1) year from the date the revocation became effective.
If the City finds, subsequent to revocation, that the basis for the revocation
has been corrected or abated, the applicant may be granted a license if at
least ninety (90) days have elapsed since the date the revocation became
effective.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.14   TRANSFER OF LICENSE.
   (a)   An adult amusement arcade license is not transferable from one (1)
licensee to another or from one location to another. Any purported transfer of
an adult amusement arcade license shall be cause to automatically and
immediately revoke that license.
   (b)   A skill-based adult amusement device license is not transferable from
one (1) device to another or to a device moved to a different location. Any
purported such transfer of a license shall be cause to automatically and
immediately revoke that license.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.15   APPEAL.
   (a)   Any licensee may appeal the decision of the Director of Public Safety
for the denial of the issuance of a license, the denial of a renewal of a
license or the revocation of a license. An appeal must be filed within ten (10)
days of notice of non-issuance, non-renewal or revocation, in writing, to the
Licensing Appeal Board, c/o Director of Public Safety, 3487 S. Smith Road,
Fairlawn, OH 44333 stating the reason for the appeal.
   (b)   The Licensing Appeal Board shall consist of three (3) residents of the
City, appointed by the Mayor, for terms of four (4) years. Appeals shall be
heard within five (5) days of filing. Such Board shall determine whether the
denial or revocation of any license under this chapter was arbitrary,
capricious or unreasonable.
   (c)   Any decision of the Board shall be a final, appealable order and the
applicant or licensee may seek prompt judicial review of such administrative
action in any court of competent jurisdiction.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.16   INSPECTION.
   (a)   The Police Department shall, from time to time and at least four (4)
times a year, inspect that portion of the adult arcade business open to the
public licensed hereunder in order to assess compliance with the provisions of
this chapter.
   (b)   The Director of Public Safety shall, from time to time, request the
Summit County Health Department to inspect that portion of each adult arcade
business open to the public and licensed hereunder, in order to assess
compliance with the provisions of this chapter and relevant Health Department
regulations.
   (c)   That the Fire Marshal and Building Commissioner shall, from time to
time, and at least four (4) times a year, inspect that portion of the adult
arcade business open to the public and licensed hereunder in order to assess
compliance with all applicable fire, building, and zoning code regulations.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.17   NUISANCE.
   (a)   A violation of this chapter shall constitute a nuisance and is subject
to civil proceedings, including an injunction, in addition to prosecution for
criminal violations of the Government of the United States; State of Ohio and
the Codified Ordinances of the City of Fairlawn.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.18   EFFECT OF PARTIAL INVALIDITY.
   (a)   If any section, subsection, or clause of this chapter shall be deemed
to be unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, the validity and enforcement of
the remaining sections, subsections, and clauses shall not be affected.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.19   FEES COLLECTED.
   (a)   All license fees collected shall be deposited into the general fund.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
814.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter, for which no penalty is otherwise provided, is guilty of a first
degree misdemeanor and shall be subject to the penalties set forth in
Chapter 698 of the Fairlawn City Code. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs.
(Ord. 2007-029A.  Passed 5-7-07.)
CHAPTER 816
Billiard Parlors, Poolrooms and Bowling Alleys (Repealed)
   Editor’s note: Chapter 816 was repealed by Ordinance 2019-078, passed
December 16, 2019.
CHAPTER 822
Discontinuing Business Sales
   
822.01   License required.
   
822.02   License application.
   
822.03   License term; fee.
   
822.04   Adding goods or merchandise.
   
822.05   Investigations; oaths.
   
822.06   Exceptions.
   
822.07   Advertising; license revocation.
   
822.08   Transfer of ownership.
   
822.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Authority of Chief of Police to license - see CHTR. Sec.
8.03
      Power to regulate advertising - see Ohio R.C. 715.65
      Falsification - see GEN. OFF.
606.10
      Theft by deception - see GEN. OFF.
642.02
      Sidewalk obstructions - see GEN. OFF.
660.10
822.01   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall advertise, announce or conduct, by any means or device, any
sale of goods, wares or merchandise, which sale is caused or occasioned by the
intention to discontinue business, unless such person is licensed as provided
herein.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.02   LICENSE APPLICATION.
   (a)   Upon application to the Chief of Police for a license, the applicant
shall make a full disclosure, under oath, of the following information:
      (1)   The true name of the owner of the goods, wares or merchandise to be
offered for sale and the name of the operator of the sale, if such operator is
a person other than the true owner; and
      (2)   A full and complete inventory of the quantity, kind and character
of the articles to be offered for sale, which inventory shall be prepared in
the following manner:
         A.   An itemized list of all articles, including the quantities
thereof remaining unsold, which have been in stock on the premises where such
sale is to be conducted for a period of fifteen days or longer prior to the
application for the license;
         B.   An itemized list of all articles and the quantities thereof
received in stock on the premises within the fifteen days immediately preceding
the application for the license; and
         C.   An itemized list of all articles and the quantities thereof which
have been ordered to be placed in stock at such premises during the pendency of
the sale and the reason for the urgent and expeditious disposal thereof.
   (b)   All articles itemized as provided in this section shall be goods,
wares or merchandise purchased by the applicant for resale on bona fide orders
without cancellation privileges and shall not comprise any articles purchased
on consignment.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.03   LICENSE TERM; FEE.
   A license issued under this chapter shall be effective for not more than
forty-five days, but may be renewed for an additional period upon satisfactory
proof that the goods itemized in the original application have not been sold.
No other such license shall be granted to the same person for one year
following the expiration of a previous license or renewal as provided herein.
The applicant for a license under this chapter shall pay to the Chief of Police
a license fee equal to one-half of one percent of the cost of merchandise
listed in the inventory required by Section 822.02, but in no event less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00).
(Ord. 1986-186. Passed 12-15-86.)
822.04   ADDING GOODS OR MERCHANDISE.
   No licensee under this chapter shall, during the continuance of the sale,
add any goods, wares or merchandise to the stock described and inventoried in
his original application for a license and no goods, wares or merchandise other
than those described and inventoried in the original application shall be sold
at or during such sale. Each addition of goods, wares or merchandise to such
stock on the premises, each sale of such goods, wares or merchandise that has
not been described and inventoried in such original application and each false
statement of fact in such application shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.05   INVESTIGATIONS; OATHS.
   The Mayor shall make or cause to be made such investigations and inquiries
throughout the conduct of any discontinuing business sale as he deems advisable
to effectuate the purposes of this chapter and the Mayor is hereby authorized
to administer oaths in connection with the taking of testimony pertaining
thereto.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.06   EXCEPTIONS.
   This chapter shall not apply to sales conducted by sheriffs, constables or
other public or court officials, nor to any person acting under the direction
or authority of any court, State or Federal, selling goods, wares and
merchandise in the course of his official duties, nor to sales conducted by
licensed auctioneers.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.07   ADVERTISING; LICENSE REVOCATION.
   (a)   If the ownership of the establishment discontinuing business has
changed hands in the twelve-month period preceding the sale, all signs and
advertising relative to the sale shall bear the name of the true owner, but may
refer to the former owner or the trade name used by him, provided that:
      (1)   Such reference is subordinated in space and letter size to the name
of the true owner; and
      (2)   All goods that are not the stock of the former owner shall be
separated and clearly identified as goods of the new owner during the course of
such sale.
   (b)   The use of any untrue, deceptive or misleading advertising and
violations of any of the provisions of this chapter shall, in addition to any
other penalty, be grounds for revocation of the license for such sale.
   (c)   All signs and other advertising of such sale shall bear the number and
date of the license issued under this chapter.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.08   TRANSFER OF OWNERSHIP.
   A business establishment owned by a corporation shall be considered to have
changed ownership upon transfer, in one or more transactions, of more than
fifty percent of the shares of such corporation to any person, whether an
individual, partnership, association or other corporation. Such individual,
partnership, association, corporation or other person so owning more than fifty
percent of the outstanding shares of a corporation owning such business
establishment shall be considered to be the true owner of such business
establishment for the purposes of this chapter.
(Ord. 1973-37. Passed 2-19-73.)
822.99   PENALTY.
   (Editor's note: See Section 810.99 for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 824
Garage Sales
   
824.01   Definitions.
   
824.02   Duration of sales.
   
824.03   Persons and sales excepted.
   
824.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Conducting business from a parked vehicle - see TRAF.
452.11
      Discontinuing business sales - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 822
824.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   “Frequency” means not more than one garage sale per month or a maximum
of two per calendar year.
   (b)   “Garage sales” means and includes all sales entitled “garage sale,”
“lawn sale,” “attic sale,” “rummage sale,” “flea market sale” or any similar
casual sale of tangible personal property which is advertised by any means
whereby the public at large is or can be made aware of such sale to be
conducted out of a residence or on land which is zoned for residential use.
   (c)   “Goods” includes any personal articles or other property capable of
being the object of a sale regulated under this chapter.
   (d)   “Person” means and includes individuals, partnerships, voluntary
associations and corporations.
(Ord. 1981-31A. Passed 6-2-81.)
824.02   DURATION OF SALES.
   Garage sales shall be limited to not more than four consecutive calendar
days.
(Ord. 1981-31A. Passed 6-2-81.)
824.03   PERSONS AND SALES EXCEPTED.
   This chapter shall not apply to or affect the following persons or sales:
   (a)   Persons selling goods pursuant to an order or process of a court of
competent jurisdiction;
   (b)   Persons acting in accordance with their powers and duties as public
officials; and
   (c)   A bona fide estate sale limited in duration to one day which has been
registered with the Chief of Police at least two days prior to the commencement
thereof.
(Ord. 1981-31A. Passed 6-2-81.)
824.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall, for a first offense, be warned, and, for a second or subsequent
offense, be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each day that the sale is in
effect.
(Ord. 1981-31A. Passed 6-2-81.)
CHAPTER 826
Late Night Retail Establishments
   
826.01   Definitions.
   
826.02   General requirements.
   
826.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Sales of alcoholic beverages - see GEN. OFF.
612.02 et seq.,
612.08
      Sales of cigarettes to minors - see GEN. OFF.
636.20
      Police and fire emergency alarms - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 840
      Signs - see B. & H.
Ch. 1468
826.01   DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   (a)   “Late Night Retail Establishment.”  Any person, partnership,
corporation or other entity who or which:
      (1)   Derives fifty percent or more of its gross income from the sale of
goods, merchandise or other articles of value; and
      (2)   Sells goods, merchandise or other articles of value in their
original containers between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.
   (b)   “Late Night Gasoline Station.”  Any person, partnership, corporation
or other entity who or which sells gasoline or other petroleum fuel to the
public between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.
   (c)   “Pay Drawer and/or Merchandise Drawer.”  A through-the-wall bullet-
resistant security transaction drawer or opening in an exterior wall of a
building approved by the Police Division which allows a retail establishment to
transact business from the establishment's building without direct customer
contact.  Such pay and/or merchandise drawer(s) must be maintained in proper
working order at all times.
   (d)   “Pay Booth.”  A structure within an establishment or gas station
constructed of windows, walls and doors as approved by the Police Division. 
Such pay booths and required equipment must be maintained in good working order
at all times.  Each pay booth must conform to the security requirements set
forth by the Police Division.
   (e)   “Video Monitoring and Recording System.”  An on-site video security
camera of a type or number approved by the Police Division.  Such camera(s)
must be capable of immediately producing a retrievable image on film or tape
that can be made a permanent record and that can be enlarged through projection
or other means.  Such video monitoring systems must be maintained in proper
working order at all times.
(Ord. 1992-172(S)(S). Passed 2-15-93.)
826.02   GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   All late night retail establishments and late night gasoline stations shall:
   (a)   Post a sign in the window which is conspicuous and which states that
there is a safe on the premises and that it is not accessible to the employees
on the premises;
   (b)   Post a sign in the window which is conspicuous and which states that
the cash register has fifty dollars ($50.00) or less in it;
   (c)   So arrange the signs posted in the windows so as to provide a clear
and unobstructed view of the interior of the store.  In no case, shall signs
obstruct the view of the register from the street;
   (d)   Have a drop-safe on the premises which is bolted to the floor, or
installed in the floor, or weighs at least 500 pounds;
   (e)   Position their registers so that they are visible from the street;
   (f)   Illuminate the entire area utilized by customers of the late night
retail establishment or late night gasoline station to park their cars at a
minimum of five foot-candles per square foot, which lighting shall be
maintained at such level.  The level of the lighting shall be measured at the
surface of the parking area.
   (g)   Install an individual alarm system directly connected to the City of
Fairlawn Communications Center;
   (h)   Continuously operate a video monitoring and recording system between
the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.;
   (i)   Have a fire extinguisher within ten feet of any cash register in
operation;
   (j)   Provide additional security measures if fewer than three employees are
working between 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m. as follows:
      (1)   Any employee operating a cash register or cash registers must
conduct business:
         A.   From a pay booth; or
         B.   By means of a pay and/or merchandise drawer or opening.
      (2)   If a pay and/or merchandise drawer or opening, or a pay booth, is
utilized, a video monitoring and recording system must be provided which
monitors the exterior area in which the pay and/or merchandise drawer or
opening, or the pay booth, is located.
   (k)   Provide employees with robbery prevention and behavior training
courses as approved by the Police Division before such employee works between
the hours of 12:00 midnight and 6:00 a.m.
(Ord. 1992-172(S)(S). Passed 2-15-93.)
826.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the third degree for a first offense and shall be fined not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00). For each subsequent offense, such person
is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than
one thousand dollars ($1,000). It is not the intent of this section that any
person be imprisoned for a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. 
It is the intent of this section that whoever violates any of the provisions of
this chapter shall be fined.
(Ord. 1992-172(S)(S). Passed 2-15-93.)
CHAPTER 828
Peddlers and Solicitors
   
828.01   Definitions.
   
828.02   Hours of solicitation regulated.
   
828.03   Commercial soliciting in Residence Districts.
   
828.04   Registration of credentials for commercial solicitors; application
fee.
   
828.05   Notice prohibiting solicitation.
   
828.06   Solicitation in violation of notice.
   
828.07   Legal action.
   
828.08   False information; revocation of registration; appeals.
   
828.09   Display of credentials upon request.
   
828.99    Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Authority of Chief of Police to license - see CHTR. Sec.
8.03
      Power to inspect food products - see Ohio R.C. 715.46
      Power to regulate - see Ohio R.C. 715.61 et seq.
      Charitable solicitations - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 1716
      Sales of goods and services within right-of-way of Interstate and other
State highways - see Ohio R.C. 5515.07
      Conducting business from parked vehicles - see TRAF.
452.11
      Placing harmful objects in food or confection - see GEN. OFF.
636.16
      Fraud - see GEN. OFF.
642.02
      Loud noises prohibited - see GEN. OFF.
648.05
      Littering - see GEN. OFF.
660.03
      Sales in parks - see S.U. & P.S.
1068.01
828.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, unless a different meaning clearly appears from the
context:
    (a)    “Commercial solicitation” and “commercial solicitor” means any
person who calls at residences without an invitation or previous consent of the
owner or occupant of such premises for the purpose of any one (1) or more of
the following activities:
         (1)   Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, investments or products or services of any kind, character or
description whatever for either present or future delivery;
         (2)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines,
periodicals, newspapers and every other kind or type of publication;
         (3)   Seeking to sell any goods, articles or services of any kind;
    (b)    “Non-commercial solicitation” and “non-commercial solicitor” means:
         (1)   Seeking to obtain from an occupant of any residence an
indication of such occupant's belief and/or support in regard to any social,
political or religious matters;
         (2)   Seeking to obtain contributions or purchase of any goods,
articles or services of any kind for the support or benefit of any educational,
civic, philanthropic, charitable, religious or non-profit association,
organization, corporation or project;
         (3)   Seeking to influence the personal belief of the occupant of any
residence in regard to any social, political or religious matter; or
         (4)   Taking a poll or census by any person, firm or corporation,
pursuant to a federal, state or local government statute or ordinance.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.02   HOURS OF SOLICITATION REGULATED.
   (a)   No commercial solicitation shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or
after sunset on weekdays and Saturdays, or at any time on Sundays or a state or
national holiday.
   (b)   No non-commercial solicitation shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or
after sunset or at any time on a state or national holiday.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.03   COMMERCIAL SOLICITING IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
   (a)   No person shall enter upon the lot or land of any residential property
situated in any residential district for the purpose of commercial solicitation
as defined in Section 828.01(a) unless such person has registered with the
Chief of Police as provided in Section 828.04.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.04   REGISTRATION OF CREDENTIALS FOR COMMERCIAL SOLICITORS; APPLICATION
FEE.
   (a)   Whoever desires to solicit for commercial purposes as defined in
Section 828.01(a) shall register with the Chief of Police or his designee,
during normal business hours, a written application on a form to be provided by
the Chief correctly setting forth the following information:
      (1)   The full name of the applicant;
      (2)   His or her current address and all residences within the immediate
prior two (2) years;
      (3)   His or her birth date, demonstrating the person is at least
eighteen (18) years of age, height, weight and color of eyes and hair;
      (4)   Whether or not he or she uses a motor vehicle in his or her
business, and if so, the make, model, year and current registration number
thereof;
      (5)   The state of issue of his or her driver's license and the number
thereof;
      (6)   Two (2) one (1) inch square photographs of applicant's face;
      (7)   The name, address and phone of his or her employer, and a contact
person therein;
      (8)   A brief description of the goods, wares, merchandise, investments,
products or services involved; and
      (9)   Whether or not he or she has ever been convicted of any crime,
other than a minor misdemeanor traffic offense, and if so, the nature thereof
and the penalty therefor.
   (b)   Concurrently with the filing of the application, the applicant shall
pay a fee of thirty-five dollars ($35.00) to compensate for the costs incident
to the background investigation, registration and issuance of stamped copies of
credentials.
   (c)   Within twenty (20) days of compliance of the foregoing provisions of
this section, the Chief shall forthwith stamp the original of the application
as “Inspected” and, if approved, deliver credentials of approval to the
applicant for identification use as hereinafter provided. Such application
shall also be stamped with the date of expiration of the registration which in
each case shall be the close of the current calendar year, or six (6) months
whichever is later.
   (d)   Possession of such stamped application shall not entitle the applicant
to enter upon any lot or land specified in Section 828.05 or between the hours
of sunset and 9:00 a.m. on weekdays and Saturdays or at any time on a state or
national holiday or Sundays nor shall such credentials be valid for the
solicitation or sale of any goods or services not disclosed in the original
application.
   (e)   Any applicant who has not reach eighteen (18) years of age shall be
required to have a parent, guardian or employer co-sign on the application.
   (f)   Any applicant who is discovered to have been convicted of, or who has
plead guilty to any criminal offense of the Ohio Revised Code, United States
Code, or any other substantially similar state or local code provisions that
constitutes any theft or fraud offense, any offense of burglary, any offenses
of violence or any offenses of a sexual nature shall be prohibited from
commercial solicitation within the City of Fairlawn.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.05   NOTICE PROHIBITING SOLICITATION.
   (a)   Notice by the owner or occupant of any residence or place of business
of its determination to refuse to receive any uninvited solicitors shall be
given by displaying a card, decal or sign, not less than three (3) inches by
six (6) inches in size nor more than one (1) square foot in total surface area,
upon or near the main entrance door to the residence or place of business,
indicating such determination by the owner or occupant, containing the words
“No Solicitors Invited,” or words of similar import, with letters at least one
(1) inch in height. Any such sign that complies with the requirements of this
section shall be exempt from any additional or different requirements contained
in the provisions of this code, including but not limited to the Planning and
Zoning Code.
   (b)   In addition to subsection (a) herein, the owner or occupant of any
residence or place of business cause to register, during normal business hours,
their residence or place of business on the “City of Fairlawn - Do Not Solicit”
list which shall be maintained by the Chief and provided to each registered
solicitor.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.06   SOLICITATION IN VIOLATION OF NOTICE.
   (a)   It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a trespass
for any person to go upon any premises and ring the door bell upon or near any
door, rap or knock upon any door or create any sound in any other manner
calculated to attract the attention of any occupant of such residence or place
of business for the purpose of commercial or non-commercial solicitation in
defiance of the notice exhibited at the residence in accordance with the
provisions of Section 828.05(a), or the “Do Not Solicit” list as contained in
828.05(b) unless the commercial or non-commercial solicitor has been previously
invited upon the premises by the owner, lessee, or an adult occupant thereof.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.07   LEGAL ACTION.
   (a)   Notwithstanding any penalty provided under the terms of this chapter,
the Director of Law or any resident of the City, or any other person, firm or
corporation, partnership or other entity may commence a civil action in any
court of competent jurisdiction against any person, firm, corporation,
partnership or other entity who violates the provisions of this chapter. Such
relief shall include any preliminary or permanent injunction to abate such
nuisance and such other relief as the court may deem appropriate, including,
but not limited to, reasonable attorney's fees, expenses and court costs.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.08   FALSE INFORMATION; REVOCATION OF REGISTRATION; APPEALS.
   (a)   No person shall make any false statement or give any false or
misleading information or omit any information requested in the application
required by Section 828.04.
   (b)   Should subsequent information disclose that an applicant has falsified
any information required in such application, the Chief shall forthwith revoke
such registration and notify the holder thereof either in person or by
certified mail of the actions so taken. Such remedy shall be in addition to any
penalty provided in Section 828.99.
   (c)   Any person whose registration is so revoked may, within ten (10) days
after receipt of the revocation notice, appeal to the Mayor by filing with the
Mayor a signed written statement briefly setting forth his ground of appeal.
The Mayor shall forthwith set a time and place for hearing such appeal and give
the appellant due notice thereof by certified mail. The appellant may appear
before the Mayor in person or by an attorney. The decision of the Mayor thereon
shall be final.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.09   DISPLAY OF CREDENTIALS UPON REQUEST.
   (a)   Any police officer of the City may require any person found engaged in
commercial solicitation for orders or selling goods, wares, merchandise,
investments or services to produce his or her credentials, and to enforce the
provisions of this chapter.
   (b)   Every holder of registered and stamped credentials, when engaged in
soliciting orders for or selling goods, wares, merchandise, investments or
services, shall, upon the request of any owner or occupant of such lot or land,
exhibit for examination his credentials issued pursuant to the provisions of
this chapter.
   (c)   Every holder of registered and stamped credentials, when engaged in
soliciting orders for or selling goods, wares, merchandise, investments or
services, shall prominently display his or her credentials in a conspicuous
place upon his or her person at all times while soliciting pursuant to this
section.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
828.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person, firm, partnership, association or corporation violating
any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a minor misdemeanor for a
first offense and a misdemeanor of the fourth degree for a subsequent offense.
(Ord. 2007-049.  Passed 9-4-07.)
CHAPTER 830
Pesticide Users
   
830.01   Definitions.
   
830.02   License required; qualifications; fee; effective period.
   
830.03   Notification to Utilities Commissioner.
   
830.04   Notification to residents.
   
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
      Environmental Services Commission - see CHTR. Art. XX; ADM.
Ch. 288
      Ohio Pesticide Law - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 921
      Unauthorized spills of hazardous materials - see GEN. OFF.
660.15
830.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the definitions set forth in Ohio R.C. Chapter 921
(the Ohio Pesticide Law) shall apply. In addition:
   (a)   “Pesticide” means:
      (1)   Any substance or mixture of substances intended for preventing,
destroying, repelling or mitigating any pest; or
      (2)   Any substance or mixture of substances intended for use as a plant
regulator, defoliant or desiccant.
   (b)   “User of pesticides” means any person who is hired to apply
pesticides, or to cause pesticides to be applied, by any means, to property or
the atmosphere incident to the application of such pesticides to trees, lawns,
shrubs and plants.
(Ord. 1988-57. Passed 4-4-88.)
830.02   LICENSE REQUIRED; QUALIFICATIONS; FEE; EFFECTIVE PERIOD.
   On and after June 1, 1988, no user of pesticides shall engage in the use or
application of pesticides within the City without first obtaining a license
therefor from the Utilities Commissioner. Users of pesticides shall provide
proof of a current Ohio Pesticide Law License, which proof shall be furnished
at the time of application. The license fee shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) per
year and the effective period for each license issued shall be one year.
(Ord. 1988-57. Passed 4-4-88.)
830.03   NOTIFICATION TO UTILITIES COMMISSIONER.
   Upon the issuance of the license referred to in Section 830.02, the user of
pesticides shall notify the Utilities Commissioner of the name, address and
telephone number of the person, persons or business entity for whom or which he
or she will be applying the pesticides, and of the generic chemical names of
pesticides to be used, in addition to any other information the Utilities
Commissioner may deem to be necessary.
(Ord. 1988-57. Passed 4-4-88.)
830.04   NOTIFICATION TO RESIDENTS.
   Each user of pesticides shall post, at the time of application of the
pesticides, warning notices on the properties involved. Such notices shall
state “Lawn Recently Sprayed - Keep Off Until Dry.”
(Ord. 1988-57. Passed 4-4-88.)
830.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the fourth degree and shall be fined not
more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) or imprisoned not more than
thirty days, or both, for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed
committed each day during or on which a violation or noncompliance occurs or
continues.
(Ord. 1988-57. Passed 4-4-88.)
CHAPTER 832
Registration of Credentials for Panhandling; Application Fee (Repealed)
   Editor’s note: Chapter 832 was repealed by Ordinance 2016-052, passed May
